awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SWIFT: SMALL: Enabling Seamless Coexistence between Passive and Active Networks using Reconfigurable Reflecting Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Harmonious coexistence between multiple wireless technologies is necessary for efficient utilization of the radio spectrum. However, enabling this in practice is known to be challenging because of the random and uncontrollable nature of the wireless channels, which makes it difficult to limit interference among co-existing wireless systems. This challenge is exacerbated by the fact that many wireless technologies, such as radio astronomy, rely on passive receivers whose performance can be disrupted by the slightest levels of interference. However, recent advances in metamaterials have made it possible to develop reconfigurable reflective surfaces (RRSs), which are electromagnetically active surfaces (e.g., a wall with wireless capabilities) that can be used to control the wireless propagation environment. Thus, RRSs can potentially help mitigate the challenge of interference among co-existing wireless technologies. The goal of this research is, thus, to develop a novel framework that will enable seamless co-existence among multiple passive and active wireless systems, by developing the fundamental science and technology needed to practically exploit the RRS concept to suppress interference at the wireless receivers. By achieving this goal, the proposed research will pave the way towards a seamless co-existence among a broad range of wireless technologies and applications. Improving these critical technologies will have tangible societal and economic impacts. The research is complemented by a comprehensive educational plan that includes spectrum-centric courses as well as the involvement of graduate and undergraduate students through diverse activities on spectrum sharing. Concrete broadening participation events, including seminars and participation in science fairs and outreach activities, are planned to engage under-represented K-12 students in spectrum research.

This research will develop foundational analytical and experimental approaches for holistic and cross-layer design, analysis, deployment, and optimization of RRS-enhanced spectrum co-existence networks. This includes several novel contributions: 1) A holistic statistical model that captures the effect of RRS deployment on the wireless propagation environment in spectrum sharing scenarios and creates RRS-inspired performance metrics tailored to spectrum co-existence use cases, 2) A systematic approach for network planning that can be used to determine how many RRSs to deploy, where,  and with what surface and orientation so as to facilitate seamless communication, 3) A novel online optimization framework for performing distributed spectrum sharing while dynamically leveraging RRS reconfigurability, and 4) Design and fabrication of an RRS that offers near-continuous beam steering capability, as well as an experimental demonstration of RRS-enhanced spectrum co-existence in practical settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this sub-project was to enhance the methodologies needed to analyze metasurface antennas, specifically extending the analytical framework to the metasurface reflectarrays needed to form reflective intelligent surfaces (RIS). A secondary goal was to develop concepts for novel antennas and devices that might be used as sources or receivers in wireless communication configuration. This subproject focused on the hardware aspects of next-generation communication schemes that also involved the development of next-generation algorithms and protocols by the team leads.

A key outcome for this subproject was the development and demonstration of a comprehensive analysis tool capable of metasurface reflectarrays. The tool makes use of the dipole framework, in which each metamaterial element is treated as a polarizable, radiating dipole. This model is generally applicable for computing the properties of metamaterial apertures provided that each radiating element is subwavelength in size. The advantage of the dipole framework is that all of the scattering characteristics of the element are incorporated into a single parameter—the dipole polarizability—with the scattered fields then found simply by summing the radiated fields from each of the dipoles. The model can be made fully self-consistent by taking interactions among the dipoles and other aspects of the geometry via analytical Green’s functions, such that the computational platform can provide modeling with accuracy similar to that of full-wave simulations. Since the entire geometry does not need to be discretized and meshed, as with full-wave solvers, extremely large apertures can be modeled and optimized quickly and efficiently using the dipole framework.

The dipole framework was extended to reflectarrays typified by arrays of patch antennas distributed atop a conducting surface. A patch antenna can be effectively modeled as a pair of polarizable magnetic dipoles, thus enabling a variation of the dipole framework to be applied. A dipole polarizability extraction procedure was developed, allowing the polarizability from an arbitrary patch design to be determined through either numerical simulations or experimental measurements. Several studies were then performed to validate the metasurface reflectarray dipole model, including a theoretical analysis of the patch resonance behavior; numerical comparison between dipole model predictions and full wave simulations; preliminary incorporation of element-element coupling via free-space Green’s functions; preliminary predictions of power and efficiency values; and experimental demonstration of the dipole-based metasurface design process. These efforts proved the utility of the dipole model for rapid design and evaluation of metasurface reflectarray structures for beamsteering applications. Experimental characterization of a binary patch reflectarray prototype indicated that the developed model accurately predicts beamsteering performance, while additional parallel studies sought to further extend the dipole framework to less conventional resonant structures including metamaterial elements and mesh patches.

To address practical implementation, an effort was launched to investigate methods of controlling the myriad patch or metamaterial elements using appropriate drive electronics and addressing schemes. As part of this effort, the team considered variants of row-column addressing schemes that mitigate the number of external electronic components and overall complexity of the electronic biasing and addressing system. The impact of these schemes on beam forming and wave-front shaping from the dynamically reconfigurable reflectarrays was also investigated. Finally, as a potential prelude to non-planar reflectarray surfaces as might be needed in various implementation scenarios, the design of conformal RIS using holographic methods and the dipole framework was evaluated, with the accuracy of the dipole framework tested against full-wave numerical simulations.

In support of the second goal of this project a number of different metasurface antenna and system concepts were considered. The concept of a reflective, complementary metamaterial metasurface useful for rejecting the spurious side lobes that plague other reconfigurable, reflective surfaces was proposed. A version of the dipole framework was adapted for this purpose, with interactions being taken into account via a coupled dipole formalism. The interactions between elements give rise to beam distortion and side lobes of the reflected beam, which can be eliminated with proper attention paid to the interelement coupling.

In addition, the concept of hybrid RIS (HRISs) was proposed and demonstrated. In conventional RIS-empowered wireless networks, the ability of RISs to mitigate interference from a secondary user on the primary user depends on the knowledge about the propagation environment and where the transmitters and receivers of the primary and secondary networks are located with respect to the RIS. Without this knowledge, the RIS is incapable of redirecting the signal toward the desired user and potentially forming a null toward the unintended users. The HRISs thus address a critical technological need to enable seamless coexistence of wireless. Once this need is addressed, the RIS geometry can be optimized to increase power toward a secondary user while forming a null toward primary users (assuming only angular information about them). In this manner, the second wireless network can operate without interfering with the primary network.
